awd_abstract_narration:
Traditionally, the main goal of cryptography has been to secure data in transit over an insecure channel, by providing the digital analogue of a "lock box" that can only be unlocked by the intended recipient but whose contents cannot be observed or manipulated by anyone else. In recent years, new technologies and applications such as the rise of cloud computing are forcing us to fundamentally change our perspective. Data is not only vulnerable while in transit, but is increasingly being stored with third-party providers that have vast storage and computational resources and are expected to offer a rich array of tools and services over this data. Traditional cryptosystems could secure the data in the cloud but only at the cost of rendering it unusable and preventing the cloud from offering any functionality over it. The goal of this project is to design a new generation of cryptostosystems that go beyond the "lock box" paradigm and allow users to cryptographically protect their data in the cloud while still enabling the cloud to perform useful computations over it. More generally, the project studies the broad question of how to enable computation over cryptographically protected data with the best possible trade-offs between security and functionality.

Specifically, the project focuses on three goals. The first goal is to construct provably secure program obfuscation schemes that can be used to encrypt a program in a way that hides its code but still allows us to evaluate it on arbitrary inputs. Such obfuscation schemes are known to be immensely powerful and would have countless applications throughout cryptography. Although this is likely to be a difficult goal and is one of the grand challenges in cryptography today, the project identifies several intermediate problems which may be closer within reach and may serve as useful stepping stones. The second goal is to improve numerous aspects of cryptosystems, such as fully homomorphic encryption and signatures. These schemes allow anyone to compute over encrypted/authenticated data and derive an encrypted/authenticated output without learning anything about the data itself. Although basic constructions of these primitives are known, they have many deficiencies that this project plans to address. Lastly, the project studies the additional challenges involved in computing over cryptographic data in the random-access machine model of computation, which best captures the efficiency requirements of real-world programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project is to construct the next generation of cryptosystems that allow computation over cryptographic data, and to do so under standard well studied computational hardness assumptions. Firstly, this project tackles the grand challenge of constructing program obfuscation (and related primitives) under standard assumptions. It does so by setting intermediate goals that may be closer within reach. Secondly, the project aims to improve many aspects of cryptosystems such as fully homomorphic encryption and signature schemes for which basic constructions are known but have many deficiencies. Lastly, the project addresses the additional challenges involved in computing over cryptographic data in the random-access machine (RAM) model of computation, which captures the efficiency requirements of real-world programs. Overall, the project aims to understand the full spectrum of security and functionality goals that cryptographic protection can provide. It simultaneously broadens our intellectual understanding of cryptography and offers novel potential solutions to some of today's most pressing security problems. The project has  resulted in many significant results published at the top venues in the field.

 

The most notable result is a breakthrough in private information retreival and fully homomorphic encryption (FHE). For example, say we wanted to execute an internet search on an encrypted search query. Using traditional FHE, the search provider would need to read the entire inernet to answer each new encrypted search query. This is because traditional FHE works in the circuit model, and the circuit corresponding to an internet search is as large as the internet. The PI's result shows how to directly evaluate standard "Random Access" programs under FHE without the overhead of translating these into a circuit. This allows the evaluation of computations such as internet search over encrypted data at an asymptotic cost which closely matches that of the plaintext computation. This work appeared at STOC 2023 and received the "best paper award".

Another notable result is the first construction of non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs (NIZKs) under standard lattice assumptions, resolving a  long standing open problem. The approach works by building a special type of correlation-intractable hash function using "encrypted computation". In particular, the hash function performs some unknown encrypted computation on the hashed data.

Lastly, the project resulted in a better understanding of obfuscation, with works that allow us to base it on a wider class of assumptions.
